content.raw: `INVALID` seems generic enough to be at risk for colliding with a macro. Consider using [Google's enum constant naming](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Enumerator_Names)?
content.html: INVALID seems generic enough to be at risk for colliding with a macro. Consider using Google's enum constant naming?

content.raw: It will be hard (or impossible) for this to collide, given the namespaces and use of `enum class`.
content.html: It will be hard (or impossible) for this to collide, given the namespaces and use of enum class.

content.raw:
`MaterialType::INVALID` won't collide. I'm pretty sure the enum declaration itself can collide.

```
#define INVALID false
#include <ignition/math/MaterialTypes.hh>
```
content.html:
MaterialType::INVALID won't collide. I'm pretty sure the enum declaration itself can collide.

#define INVALID false
#include <ignition/math/MaterialTypes.hh>

content.raw:
Just to elaborate on this explanation: Macros don't care about namespaces or scope. If anyone anywhere has defined a macro named `INVALID`, then there can be a collision.

You'd think developers would be sensible enough to not `#define` a macro as generic as `INVALID`, but MSVC headers define a macro named `NO_ERROR` which has bitten us in the past.
content.html:
Just to elaborate on this explanation: Macros don't care about namespaces or scope. If anyone anywhere has defined a macro named INVALID, then there can be a collision.

You'd think developers would be sensible enough to not #define a macro as generic as INVALID, but MSVC headers define a macro named NO_ERROR which has bitten us in the past.

content.raw: Alternatively, we could name this something like `INVALID_MATERIAL` or `MATERIAL_ENUM_COUNT`.
content.html: Alternatively, we could name this something like INVALID_MATERIAL or MATERIAL_ENUM_COUNT.

content.raw: INVALID_MATERIAL sounds good to me.
content.html: INVALID_MATERIAL sounds good to me.

After completing the code review, I realized that all user-defined materials will end up with an `INVALID_MATERIAL` "type", even if it's a perfectly valid material that we just didn't predefine.

Would it be okay for me to rename this to `UNKNOWN_MATERIAL`?

content.raw: Why have a name? Built-in materials already have an enum `MaterialType` with the same information. It doesn't seem important to the class itself since `operator==()` is ignoring it. Even a user that really wants a name could subclass or store a name adjacent.
content.html: Why have a name? Built-in materials already have an enum MaterialType with the same information. It doesn't seem important to the class itself since operator==() is ignoring it. Even a user that really wants a name could subclass or store a name adjacent.

content.raw: Material density has always had a name, see MaterialDensity in ign-common. Names have been important, and I don't want to remove them. Operator== doesn't use it on purpose. The equal operator is operating only on density values.
content.html: Material density has always had a name, see MaterialDensity in ign-common. Names have been important, and I don't want to remove them. Operator== doesn't use it on purpose. The equal operator is operating only on density values.

content.raw: Why does `MaterialDensity` have a name?
content.html: Why does MaterialDensity have a name?

content.raw:
1. Material density in ign-common had a name.
2. I have found names to be valuables.
3. Removing it does not seem to solve any problem.
4. It supports creating materials not defined in the enum. And yes, there are multiple ways that this could be supported. This is the method I have chosen.
content.html:
1. Material density in ign-common had a name.
  2. I have found names to be valuables.
  3. Removing it does not seem to solve any problem.
  4. It supports creating materials not defined in the enum. And yes, there are multiple ways that this could be supported. This is the method I have chosen.

content.raw: What's the purpose of this method? Is it to allow user code to print out all built-in types?  Returning a reference to the map sort of exposes an implementation detail. Now the implementation must use a map for storage as long as this method exists.
content.html: What's the purpose of this method? Is it to allow user code to print out all built-in types? Returning a reference to the map sort of exposes an implementation detail. Now the implementation must use a map for storage as long as this method exists.

content.raw: This function must return a map, but that doesn't constrain the storage. And yes, this is a convenience method to get all the built-in types.
content.html: This function must return a map, but that doesn't constrain the storage. And yes, this is a convenience method to get all the built-in types.

content.raw:
True, if the function returned a map it wouldn't constrain the storage. The function returns a reference to a map so there must be a permanently stored map somewhere.

I was wrong about it requiring a map for storage. If we want to get rid of this function in the future we could have it a static variable in the function's scope, populate it on the first call, and return a reference to that.
content.html:
True, if the function returned a map it wouldn't constrain the storage. The function returns a reference to a map so there must be a permanently stored map somewhere.

I was wrong about it requiring a map for storage. If we want to get rid of this function in the future we could have it a static variable in the function's scope, populate it on the first call, and return a reference to that.

content.raw: At that point we'd be double-storing this data, but at least it would be a viable way to tic-toc this.
content.html: At that point we'd be double-storing this data, but at least it would be a viable way to tic-toc this.

content.raw:
Water is a liquid, but all the other materials are solids. If the only parameter we want to store is density, then I think it's ok to include a liquid, but how will we handle liquids when we add other properties like friction or Young's modulus?

Maybe we should have separate data structures for solids, liquids, and gases?
content.html:
Water is a liquid, but all the other materials are solids. If the only parameter we want to store is density, then I think it's ok to include a liquid, but how will we handle liquids when we add other properties like friction or Young's modulus?

Maybe we should have separate data structures for solids, liquids, and gases?

content.raw:
Maybe I'm not fully aware of all the uses for these presets, but the use-case I can think of is to have handy approximations for users to drop into their models.

If that's the case, I think we should strive for intuitive values.  I personally think phases for things other than water are not very intuitive. Along the same line, "water" immediately reminds liquid water, especially when listed next to ice, and it is the one density value most people can remember by heart. So I vote for leaving it in, since it is a nice intuitive value to compare to.
content.html:
Maybe I'm not fully aware of all the uses for these presets, but the use-case I can think of is to have handy approximations for users to drop into their models.

If that's the case, I think we should strive for intuitive values. I personally think phases for things other than water are not very intuitive. Along the same line, "water" immediately reminds liquid water, especially when listed next to ice, and it is the one density value most people can remember by heart. So I vote for leaving it in, since it is a nice intuitive value to compare to.

content.raw: Oh I should also mention I wasn't being serious about temperatures :smile:

content.raw: :sweat_smile:

Yeah, I see these enumerations as a zeroth-order (even lower than first-order) pass at a materials "database". It seems like the scope of this is to provide users with a convenient way of scooping up the densities of some very common, basic materials so they can give sane mass values to their models.

I suspect that when it comes time to expand the scope of this (e.g. accounting for friction, Young's modulus, phases, temperature, etc), we'll want to do a complete redesign of this, probably getting rid of enumerations entirely in favor of something more extensible, like interfaces, inheritance, and database queries.
content.html:
Yeah, I see these enumerations as a zeroth-order (even lower than first-order) pass at a materials "database". It seems like the scope of this is to provide users with a convenient way of scooping up the densities of some very common, basic materials so they can give sane mass values to their models.

I suspect that when it comes time to expand the scope of this (e.g. accounting for friction, Young's modulus, phases, temperature, etc), we'll want to do a complete redesign of this, probably getting rid of enumerations entirely in favor of something more extensible, like interfaces, inheritance, and database queries.

content.raw:
We don't need to analyze this. I'm copying what existed in ign-common to ign-math so that sdformat can make use of material properties without depending on ign-common.

These material properties also are a nice fit for ign-math, especially when it comes to computing density/mass properties of shapes in the other pull requests.
